WRITING.TEXT:
This isn't about a simple black-and-white "people are inherently good and civilised" vs. "people are inherently violent and cruel" argument. Both of those statements are utterly reductive and unhelpful.
My premise is that rape and murder are behaviours that occurred naturally in humans since the beginning of the species. And probably at no time in history has there been *less* rape and murder than today (even though there is still way too much), thanks to our collective cultural efforts to *counter* people's natural impulsive behaviours when they are too harmful.
Just because something is 'natural' doesn't automatically mean it's constructive, sustainable or helpful.

Bei der Sparkasse Kln-Bonn gehe es aktuell jeweils um Einlagen in einer Hhe von mehreren Millionen Euro, um die aus der EZB resultierenden Zinsbelastung in Teilen aufzufangen und nicht lnger in vollem Umfang subventionieren zu mssen.
(...)
Bei den einzelnen Sparkassen, die dazu bergingen, fr bestimmte Kundengruppen Verwahrentgelte zu berechnen, gehe es um Einlagen von mehreren Millionen Euro: Damit stellen die Institute sicher, dass fr die Breite der Sparer solche Entgelte auch in der Zukunft nicht berechnet werden mssen.
Milionrssteuer anyone?

Als Veganer und Tierschtzer mchte ich hier differenzieren:
Die Sabotageaktion mit dem Lastwagen auf der Autobahn halte ich fr absolut irrsinnig und zutiefst zu verurteilen! Keine tierschtzerische Aktion tut sich oder irgendjemandem einen Gefallen, indem sie Menschen verletzt - oder in solche Verletzungsgefahr bringt!
Auf der anderen Seite finde ich es berzogen, Einbrche von Aktivisten, die schreckliche Haltungszustnde der Tiere filmen und dokumentieren, hiermit in die gleiche Schublade zu stecken und unter dem gleichen Label von "Radikalisierung" zu fhren!
Dass letzteres rein juristisch strafbar ist, steht auer Frage, aber hier sehe ich das hnlich wie den Fall von Edward Snowden: manchmal mssen Gesetze gebrochen werden, um die Wahrheit ber Ungerechtigkeit und Misshandlung ans Licht zu bringen.
Und ein zerbrochenes Vorhngeschloss ist wohl kaum damit gleichzusetzen, wenn jemand einen LKW-Fahrer auf der Autobahn in Lebensgefahr bringt.

Humans are omnivores. This is the way nature made us.
Humans are also murderers and rapists by nature.
Yet we have come to a level of civilisation where we socially accept that causing pain and suffering to other creatures for our own advantage or pleasure is not acceptable.
I think it's only reasonable that, as our collective social/cultural morality evolves further, we extend this to animals.

WRITING.TEXT: In the upcoming years and decades we'll have to make *much more radical* changes to our economic and welfare systems than to keep the birth rate at replacement levels and hoping things can continue as they have in the 20th century.

Not sure what you want to hear to be honest.
It works, it's well-known and frequently covered in the media, it's a gemeinntziger (=nonprofit) [eingetragener Verein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eingetragener_Verein), so nothing shady if that's what you're worried about.

* https://arstechnica.com/business/2016/12/federal-report-ai-could-threaten-up-to-47-percent-of-jobs-in-two-decades/
* http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2017/02/07/automation-dominic-barton_n_14634612.html
* https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/oct/25/850000-public-sector-jobs-automated-2030-oxford-university-deloitte-study

I agree. We need to become way more efficient. But it's unrealistic to expect a 6.07x raise in efficiency (which would be necessary for the US to reach 2.7 tons CO2 per capita per year) without any reductions in material, energy and other resource consumption (like mobility for example - transport and flying is a *massive* environmental hazard).
We need to help curb population growth faster and reduce consumption and increase efficiency for the areas where consumption cannot realistically be reduced.
And don't get me wrong, nobody is saying we should *forbid* people to have children! I'm not advocating a global tyrannical one-child policy - that would lead to conflicts and suffering. What I'm saying is that we need to put more effort into accelerating the *natural and voluntary* reduction in birth rates that have proven to occur in all countries where women's rights are strenghtened (i.e. they're allowed to work, vote, and find other purpose in life than just being a mother), education is raised and contraceptives are made more accessible.
Nobody *forced* Germany, Japan or other first world countries to lower their birth rates - yet in all developed countries it is much lower than in most developing ones.

The growth rate is slowing but the world population is still growing.
Just like how sitting in a car, you can decrease your *acceleration* but your *speed* will still increase as long as your acceleration is larger than 0.
Why? The earth can sustain a huge number of people. What needs to be addressed is consumption/waste, not population numbers.
If we want to meet the 2 degree maximum climate warming goal, the world's population can only produce 2.7 [tons of CO2 per year per person](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions_per_capita). Germany is at around 9.2 right now. The USA is at 16.4. So unless we all agree to live at no higher than the standard of living of Ecuador, we need to reduce the world population.
Of course you're free to convince everyone in the first world to reduce their consumption and waste down to the level of Ecuador or Brazil, but I think it would be easier to have fewer children than to fight against people's [loss aversion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loss_aversion).
The practical reality is that we need to do *both* because no single solution alone will suffice and succeed to a sufficient degree. I.e. we need to reduce world population *and* our consumption levels in reasonable measures.
Check out **[Dr. Niko Paech's talks](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eeb3h9sBm0Y)** on the subject of /r/degrowth.
(Also a related [blog post](http://lykkelykke.de/2015/04/dr-niko-paech-europa-ist-eine-maschine-der-zerstoerung/)).

It's not the same, but it's a bit like a heroin dealer who himself stays clean - because he knows heroin isn't good for his health.
Actually, it's not even an apt comparison because a big part of the addiction in social media isn't just from *reading* other content but from the gratification one receives from other people's responses to one's own content. So you're still addicted.

I'm talking about controlled immigration of skilled workers. You can argue about how the German government handled the refugee crisis but even leaving refugees aside entirely, Germany is doing a better job at attracting skilled immigrants who contribute to the economy.
Japan is in a more problematic position here - and its deep-rooted culture of xenophobia isn't helping here.

WRITING.TEXT: I'm assuming it was in there for an American audience, in order to take the wind out of the inevitable Nazi criticisms he'd be confronted with for giving a "Germany does X better than the USA" talk by some Americans.

We need to start thinking globally. There's no 'sustainable birth rate' in isolation - it depends on world population as well as average resource consumption per capita *globally*.
If we have a world population with an average consumption per capita that is *sustainable* (which we currently don't - even though a majority of the world is *way behind* the US or Germany in terms of consumption), then a **[replacement rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_fertility_rate#Replacement_rates)** of little above 2.0 would be sustainable.
The replacement fertility rate is roughly 2.0 births per woman for most industrialized countries (2.075 in the UK, for example), but ranges from 2.5 to 3.3 in developing countries because of higher mortality rates. Taken globally, the total fertility rate at replacement is 2.33 children per woman. At this rate, global population growth would tend towards zero.
It's a lot easier to adjust our economic systems than it is to break the physical limits of the planet. That doesn't mean adjusting our economic systems isn't politically and culturally challenging - it only means that the alternative is impossible.
Jesus Christ Reddit ;)

Of course we do - and we are. For example in Democratic Republic of Congo the birth rate is at 6.04 (down from 7.25 in 1994), and we need to further encourage education (sexual and otherwise) and women's rights, access to contraceptives, etc.
In Germany we certainly don't need to further *decrease* it, but it also doesn't make sense to subsidise a *higher* birth rate here.

WRITING.TITLE: TEDx Jeff Rosen - Germany: Low Crime, Clean Prisons, Lessons for America

WRITING.TEXT:
It is already an issue because the world population is still increasing (and will continue to do so for decades) and people's consumption is increasing way faster than can be offset by the lowering birth rates.
Even if we froze all *increases* in consumption rates of today and continued to consume at current rates, the planet's resources would not be enough for us to do so sustainably. But in reality we are far from that - we're still *increasing* our consumption globally.
Time **is** an issue here.

WRITING.TEXT: If you look at the **[world population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population)**, there's absolutely no need to 'tackle population decline' - at least definitely not by subsidising having more children.

Exactly! **This** is the discussion we need to have!
Not the short-sighted *"Ermagerd, the world's gonna run out of pure-blood Germans!"*
The world population is exploding. Having a low birth rate like Japan or Germany is a *good* thing. Where necessary, population decline needs to be offset by controlled immigration - something Germany is doing a far better job at than Japan.
All countries need to move towards lowering their birth rate to, or ideally below, replacement levels. Thankfully, birth rates are dropping globally.
